title: Picadero JC
text:
Picadero Jockey Club, also known until 1970 as Picadero <a href="S.A.%20Damm">Damm</a> for sponsorship reasons, was a Spanish multisports club from <a href="Barcelona">Barcelona</a> founded in 1951.
History.
Overall the club enjoyed its golden era during the 1960s. Throughout this decade its <a href="basketball">men's basketball</a> team won two <a href="Copa%20del%20Rey%20de%20Baloncesto">Spanish Cups</a> in 1964 and 1968 and was the runner-up of the <a href="Liga%20Nacional%20de%20Baloncesto">Spanish League</a> for three years in a row (1964–66) and in 1970, while its <a href="women%27s%20basketball">women's basketball</a> reached the <a href="Copa%20de%20la%20Reina%20de%20Baloncesto">Spanish Cup</a>'s final in 1960 and was the following year the first Spanish team to enter the <a href="Euroleague%20Women">Women's Basketball European Cup</a> after <a href="CD%20Cottet">CD Cottet</a> renounced for financial reasons, losing to <a href="Sportif%20Casablancais">Sportif Casablancais</a> in the <a href="1960%E2%80%9361%20European%20Cup%20%28women%27s%20basketball%29">qualification round</a>.
While Picadero is most remembered for its basketball teams, the club's <a href="Picadero%20JC%23Baseball%20section">baseball section</a> was its most successful team in the international scene, winning the inaugural edition of the <a href="European%20Cup%20%28baseball%29">European Cup</a> in 1963 and a second trophy five years later. Picadero's <a href="women%27s%20handball">team handball</a> team won four <a href="Divisi%C3%B3n%20de%20Honor%20Femenina%20de%20Balonmano">Spanish Leagues</a> in a row between 1964 and 1967 and a fifth one in 1970, while its <a href="volleyball">men's volleyball</a> team won the first two editions of the <a href="Superliga%20de%20Voleibol%20Masculina">Spanish League</a> in 1965 and 1966. Picadero also had <a href="rink%20hockey">rink hockey</a>, <a href="cycle%20sport">cycling</a> and <a href="Rugby%20football">rugby</a> teams.
The 1970s meant the beginning of the end for Picadero JC as the club collapsed financially. Picadero had to close most of its sections, and soon only the women's basketball team remained. However the team, known for sponsorship reasons as PICEFF Barcelona, Picadero Evax, Íntima Barcelona, Picadero Comansi and finally Natural Cus, experienced its golden years in this period, winning six <a href="Liga%20Femenina%20de%20Baloncesto">Spanish Leagues</a> between 1975 and 1983 and reaching the European Cup's quarter-final group stages in 1977 and 1979. In addition the team won seven national Cups, achieving doubles in 1975, 1978, 1980 and 1983. The 1985 Cup was its last national title and the team was also disbanded in 1989, ending Picadero JC's history.
Baseball section.
Picadero Damm was the commercial name of the <a href="baseball">baseball</a> team from the Picadero JC in <a href="Barcelona">Barcelona</a>, <a href="Catalonia">Catalonia</a> (Spain) during the heyday of baseball in Spain in the 1950s and 1960s. Picadero Jockey Club is now a defunct sports club who had also basketball and handball teams. The commercial name was due to its main <a href="Sponsor%20%28commercial%29">sponsor</a>, <a href="S.A.%20Damm">S.A. Damm</a>, a well-known Barcelona brewery.
Picadero Damm won the II Copa del Mediterráneo prize in 1965, two <a href="European%20Cup%20%28baseball%29">European Cups</a> (1963 and 1968) and three <a href="Divisi%C3%B3n%20de%20Honor%20de%20B%C3%A9isbol">Spanish leagues</a> (1957, 1962 and 1964).
Basketball section.
Basketball men's team played in the top league, <a href="Liga%20Espa%C3%B1ola%20de%20Baloncesto%20%281957%E2%80%931983%29">Liga Española de Baloncesto</a>, from 1960 to 1973. In 1973, this section was folded. During these years, Picadero won two <a href="Copa%20del%20Rey%20de%20Baloncesto">King's Cup</a> and played three times in European competitions.
The women's team played in <a href="Liga%20Femenina%20de%20Baloncesto">Liga Femenina de Baloncesto</a> until 1985, year were the section was dissolved, and won several leagues and <a href="Copa%20de%20la%20Reina%20de%20Baloncesto">Cups</a>.
